Digital twins (DTs) are emerging as powerful tools in the energy sector, offering virtual replicas of physical systems for improved decision-making and performance optimization (Pietrantoni et al., 2024; Ismail et al., 2024). DTs are being applied across various energy subsystems, including generation, storage, transmission, and consumption (Amaral et al., 2023). Integration with XR technologies enhances their potential for human factors engineering and training (Roy et al., 2024). However, challenges remain in assessing human trust in autonomous systems and DTs (Doroftei et al., 2021). The development of open architecture frameworks and technology stacks could facilitate wider adoption of DTs in the energy sector (Gourisetti et al., 2023). Recent trends show increasing interest in DT applications for energy efficiency and clean energy transition (Ghenai et al., 2022). In battery energy storage systems, DTs are valuable for fault detection, monitoring, and optimization (Semeraro et al., 2023). Overall, DTs offer significant potential for improving energy system performance and decision-making processes.
